feed.title: Baluk willum nature conservation reserve belgrave

entry.title: Pterostylis grandiflora
entry.content: A small plant about 10 cm high with lance-shaped leaves. The flowers were attractive with the central sepal (green) and lateral petals (brown) fused to form a hood, rising up and over the labellum. The lateral sepals were fused at the base and rose up on either side to erect points. The inside of the hood showed broad white stripes (pic 5). The same colouring could be seen on the outer side of the flower (pic 3).

entry.title: Poranthera microphylla s.s.
entry.content: Herbaceous plant about 5 cm tall with erect stems bearing clusters of small white flowers. Leaves were elongated egg-shaped, some small and some large. The plant had bright green loculated fruit.

entry.title: Thelymitra ixioides s.l.
entry.content: Tall plant with beautiful blue flowers with purplish tinge ot the outer surface of sepals. Yellow pollinia was visible at the tip of the column. Stigmatic surface showed a dense tuft of white hairs. Leaves were erect and narrow ( not seen here). Spotted in semi-shade in a reserve with eucalypts and natives - dry sclerophyll forest. The flowers bloom in October and November.

entry.title: Microtis arenaria
entry.content: Called the "Notched Onion-orchid" this orchid plant was about 50 cm high. I could see a single long sheath like leaf from the centre of which rose a slender green stem bearing a spike of flowers. The central sepal was hooded covering the petals. Lateral sepals curled backwards. The lip was bilobed with a slightly wavy margin. At first this plant looked like it had unopened buds- the flowers were so small and are not conspicuous. They are apparently scented ! Spotted in semi-shade.
